description: From Middle English erwigge, from Old English ēarwicga, from ēare (“ear”) +‎ wicga (“insect”), so named from a popular belief that they crawl into the ear and cause injury.

entries.meaning: Any of various insects of the order Dermaptera that have elongated bodies, large membranous wings folded underneath short leathery forewings and a pair of large pincers protruding from the rear of the abdomen.
examples: Nuthatches search the crevices of bark at other times during the year for insects, including beetles, earwigs, flies and bugs, and they open galls (swellings in plants) to extract grubs.

entries.meaning: One who whispers insinuations; a secret counsellor.

verbs.description: earwig (third-person singular simple present earwigs, present participle earwigging, simple past and past participle earwigged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill the mind of with prejudice by insinuations.
(transitive) To attempt to influence by persistent confidential argument or talk.
examples: In the interim, rest assured that Mr. Atherstone is by no means your friend, for he was perpetually earwigging poor Sir Rowland.

The nameless earwigging writer scrawled in his notebook that “MS and CT also considered that such low life would have a greater pride and satisfaction in life if they could themselves be cooked and served still bleating to rich diners.″
